cards.back: Where gain drops to 0.707 of midband voltage gain (half power). Defines bandwidth: BW = fH - fL.
Check DC operating point — verify node voltages match calculations. If DC is wrong, AC is meaningless.

cards.front: How to select coupling capacitor value?
cards.back: Xc << R at operating frequency. C > 10/(2πfR). For Cin at 1kHz with Zin=8kΩ: C > 0.2μF → choose 2.2μF.

cards.front: Flat bottom on output waveform means?
cards.back: Saturation clipping — VCE dropped below VCEsat. Q-point may be too high or swing too large.

cards.front: Flat top on output waveform means?
cards.back: Cutoff clipping — VCE tried to exceed VCC region. Q-point may be too low.

cards.front: What does the bypass capacitor CE do?
cards.back: Shorts R2 at AC frequencies, increasing gain. Without it, R2 adds emitter degeneration and reduces gain.

cards.front: Why do SPICE results differ from hand calculations?
cards.back: SPICE uses full nonlinear models (Gummel-Poon). Our h-parameter model is a simplified linearisation. 5-15% difference is normal.

cards.front: Expected midband phase for this amplifier?
cards.back: ≈ 180° (inverting amplifier). Phase shifts away from 180° at frequencies near fL and fH.
Change ONE component at a time. Observe effect. Understand why. Then iterate. Never change multiple things simultaneously.
